node.text: The race between covid-19 vaccines and variants is on. Alok Jha, The Economist’s science correspondent, and Natasha Loder, our health policy editor, discuss what this means for the future. Cover image credit: Alamy

node.title: Covid-19: can vaccines keep up with variants?

node.text: The Taliban’s swift return to power in Afghanistan has shocked the world and humiliated America. What effect will this have on the international standing of the US and on global security? Our experts answer your questions. Cover credit: AP

node.title: Afghanistan: how the Taliban weakened America

node.text:
Most governments recognise that vaccination is the fastest way out of the pandemic, but in many places hesitancy is hindering the roll-out. Should employers—or even governments—force people to have the vaccine? We answer your questions.

Cover image credit:

node.text:
The covid-19 pandemic has reinforced humanity’s dependence on modern tech, but the same tools that enable remote working are also being used to spread disinformation and perpetuate cybercrime. Ambivalence towards technology is nothing new.

Cover image credit: Scott Strazzante/The San Francisco Chronicle via Getty Images

node.text:
More than 50 countries around the world have pledged to become net zero. But what does net zero actually mean—and is it achievable?

Cover image credit: Brandon Thibodeaux/ The New York Times / Redux / eyevine

node.text:
In the past couple of weeks South Africa has witnessed the worst violence since the end of apartheid in 1994. Our correspondent in Johannesburg explains what he has seen on the streets and why the country is in crisis. 

Cover credit: Getty Images

node.title: South Africa: what's behind the riots?

node.text:
In America, the intelligence services deem far-right extremism a greater domestic threat than Islamist terrorism. The pandemic has exacerbated the spread of white supremacism and neo-Nazism.

Cover image credit: Michael Nigro/Pacific Press/LightRocket via Getty Images

node.title: Fortnite to far right: the rise of digital extremism

node.text:
Across much of the world, covid-19 restrictions are starting to ease. The Economist has crunched the data to calculate how close countries are to pre-pandemic levels of normality—but will life ever be the same again? 

Click on the link in our bio to visit our website and explore our interactive normalcy tracker. It covers 50 countries which account for 76% of the world’s population and 90% of its GDP.

Cover image credit: Lluis Gene/AFP via Getty Images

node.title: Covid-19: why your life will never be the same again

node.text:
As debates over vaccinating children rage and the Delta variant surges in many countries, what impact will the return to classrooms have on the covid-19 pandemic? Mike Tildesley from University of Warwick’s School of Life Sciences joins our “Babbage” podcast to explain the trade-offs in schools during the pandemic.⁠
⁠
Also on the podcast, our science correspondent Alok Jha asks ecologist Meg Lowman about the secrets that can be revealed by exploring the treetops. And the northern white rhino is nearing extinction, but can technology bring this species back from the brink?⁠
⁠
To learn more about the latest in science and technology, click the link in our bio to listen to “Babbage”.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in Caracas. May be an image of 3 people and text that says 'The Americas Nicolás Maduro's regime and the Venezuelan opposition meet in Mexico Ventud ค5'.

node.text:
Nicolás Maduro’s dictatorial regime is meeting with its Venezuelan opposition in Mexico. Negotiations may go on for months or even years.⁠
⁠
Unlike previous talks in Barbados in 2019 and the Dominican Republic in 2017, which were low-key affairs, the meetings in Mexico have international backers.⁠
⁠
Although Mr Maduro is supported by only 16% of Venezuelans, he has all the guns and is prepared to use them. The opposition are exhausted, hungry and scared. ⁠
⁠
The Biden administration has said it is prepared to offer some relief. It will do so once Mr Maduro’s regime shows it has changed its ways.⁠
⁠
Few ordinary Venezuelans expect the Mexico talks to achieve much. But the participants seem strangely confident that change is possible. Tap on the link in our bio to read more.⁠
⁠
Credit: Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in Berlin, Germany. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'German election 2021 Armin Laschet's showing is lacklustre. Could Angela Merkel's party lose office?'.

node.text:
Armin Laschet had hoped to coast to victory in Germany’s election this month. ⁠
⁠
Instead, the candidate of the the CDU/CSU finds himself leading a campaign that has disintegrated more quickly than even his biggest foes can have hoped.⁠
⁠
As the candidate for a grouping that has led Germany’s government for a decade-and-a-half under Angela Merkel, Mr Laschet is caught in an awkward position: pledging change, but not so much as to disturb a conservative electorate broadly content with the direction of the country. ⁠
⁠
But he has struggled to find a consistent explanation for why he, and not one of his rivals, deserves to run the country. ⁠
⁠
According to polls, many more Germans would rather give the job to Olaf Scholz of the centre-left Social Democrats. Click the link in our bio to learn why Mr Laschet floundering, and what this might mean for Angela Merkel’s party.⁠
⁠
Credit: Michael Kappeler/DPA

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 03, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'The Paralympics have gone from strength to strength Countries competing 200 150 100 1960 50 84* 2000 *Average of the two games held that year *Includes a team of refugee athletes International Paralympic Committee 20t The Economist'.

node.text:
In the summer of 1964 Japan staged the second Paralympic Games, bringing together 378 athletes to compete in nine sports. Much has changed for the games since then. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The Paralympics started small. Born out of an archery and netball competition held at a hospital for British veterans in 1948, the first games in Rome in 1960 featured 400 competitors.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Fast forward to 2021: 4,403 participants from 161 countries and a team of refugee athletes are competing. More female athletes will compete than ever before.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
As the Paralympics draw to a close, tap the link in our bio to learn how the games are not just an athletic spectacle, but a powerful political statement.

node.text:
Japan’s prime minister is stepping aside. Suga Yoshihide will not stand for re-election when his Liberal Democratic Party votes for its president at the end of the month.⁠
⁠
A year ago his cabinet began with approval ratings above 70%. They have now dipped below 30% in some polls.⁠
⁠
Mr Suga’s main problem has been inability to communicate effectively with the public. During times of crisis, that is what people want from their leader.⁠
⁠
There have been some successes: he set a goal to be carbon neutral by 2050, and Japan has seen fewer covid-19 deaths, both in absolute and proportional terms, than any other G7 country.⁠
⁠
But overall, he has been unpopular and uninspiring. Click the link in our bio to read why.⁠
⁠
Illustration: @elenaxausa

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 03, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'The broken evacuation system shows how the world has failed Afghanistan Summia Tora'.

node.text:
Summia Tora began trying to evacuate her father from Afghanistan two days before the collapse of the state.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Writing for The Economist, she recounts the "deeply unfair" process—and argues that it shows how the world failed her country.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
As the first Rhodes scholar from Afghanistan, she writes that she was able to attract interest in her father's story and access networks needed to help him escape. But, she asks, "how would someone without such a platform, or some other influential position, even begin to help family members in the same situation as my father?"⁠⁠
⁠⁠
"The focus now should be on ordinary Afghans who could not access their own national airport, and who got left behind because of mismanagement, and a dearth of foreign connections."⁠⁠
⁠⁠
"We should debunk the mythology of heroic foreign rescue missions and the images which accompany them," she adds. To read how she is continuing to work on evacuating families from Afghanistan, and why now is the time to ask difficult questions, click on the link in our bio.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Illustration: @dan.will

Photo by The Economist in Russia. May be an image of 3 people, people standing and text that says 'Europe Vladimir Putin's henchmen target Russia's universities and students'.

node.text:
⁠The unsuccessful attempt to kill Alexei Navalny with poison on a plane a year ago marked the start of a new wave of repression in Russia.⁠
⁠
Russian students and young people, once lauded by the Kremlin as part of Vladimir Putin’s base, are now seen as one of the biggest dangers to its power. ⁠
⁠
In the past nine months some 20 universities and institutes across Russia have had their deans replaced.⁠
⁠
In July the Kremlin “accepted” the resignation of Yaroslav Kuzminov, the head of the Higher School of Economics, better known as HSE, Russia’s first and most successful post-Soviet university.⁠
⁠
Mr Putin, who will turn 70 next year, has plenty of repressive tools at his disposal. But the young have one crucial advantage. Time is on their side, not his.⁠
⁠
There’s an election coming, click the link in our bio to find out whether it will change anything.⁠
⁠
Credit: Ivan Vodop'janov/Kommersant/Sipa USA

node.text:
⁠Hurricane Ida made landfall in the United States this week. It is the fifth most powerful ever to do so. ⁠
⁠
As millions of people in Louisiana and Mississippi were left without power, researchers from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration were flying into the eye of the storm to collect valuable data.⁠
⁠
The clip above shows the crew of a Lockheed WP-3D Orion “Hurricane Hunter” aeroplane called Miss Piggy, as it breaks through the storm wall and penetrates to the eerie calm behind.⁠
⁠
If you're interested in the world of science, sign up to "Simply Science", our free weekly newsletter. ⁠ ⁠ ⁠
⁠
This week's newsletter focuses on the differences between artificial intelligence and human reasoning as well as gene editing. ⁠
⁠
Credit: Lt Cmdr Doremus/NOAA

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 02, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Leaders Americas should engage with the Taliban, very cautiously'.

node.text:
⁠The last American soldiers left Kabul on August 30th, ending the 20-year effort to shape events in⁠
Afghanistan directly. ⁠
⁠
America and its allies must now decide how best to influence the country from a distance. America owes it to Afghans to try to make the situation it has bequeathed them less awful. ⁠
⁠
Aside from helping ordinary Afghans, America's most pressing interest is to prevent the nation from becoming a breeding ground for terrorism. ⁠
⁠
It will be impossible to achieve either of those goals, however, without some sort of dealings with the Taliban.⁠
⁠
To read about how America and its allies do now have genuine, if limited, leverage, tap the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Credit: New York Times / Redux / eyevine

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 02, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Leaders Delta continues to interfere with the global supply of goods As the virus has changed, so has the economy'.

node.text:
The Delta variant looks like a stagflationary force that saps growth less dramatically but sends inflation up. ⁠
⁠
In countries with lots of vaccine, the link between more cases and less mobile consumers has weakened. Europe’s service sector has reopened amid its Delta wave.⁠
⁠
Should the spread of Delta interfere with service industries such as leisure and hospitality, more stimulus will only create more inflation.⁠
⁠
The Delta wave may subside soon, easing the pressure on the world economy. If it does not or another variant takes its place, the trade-offs involved in fighting the virus will become harder to justify. Tap on the link in our bio to read more.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 02, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'The Economist Covid's stagflationary consequences Was Macron right about America? China' bad- -debt problem Meetings after covid: Zoom or room? SEPTEMBER4T The threat from the illiberal left'.

node.text:
Populists and illiberal progressives feed off each other pathologically. Their hatred of each other starves classical liberals of oxygen.⁠
⁠
Superficially, the illiberal left and classical liberals want many of the same things.⁠
⁠
Both believe that people should be able to flourish whatever their sexuality or race. They share a suspicion of authority and entrenched interests. They believe in the desirability of change. ⁠
⁠
But no-platforming and cancel culture show how much they disagree more over how to bring them about—and their difference in method has profound implications. ⁠
⁠
Classical liberals must understand what they are up against and rediscover their fighting spirit. To read why the ultimate complacency would be for them to underestimate the threat, click on the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Cover illustration: @dougchayka

node.text:
The true death toll of covid-19 is dramatically different from official death tallies.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The Economist started with a simple premise: the pandemic’s death toll is “excess deaths”: how many deaths there have been compared to normal years since the pandemic began.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
By estimating how many have gone uncounted, our data teams show that the true toll is much higher than official death tallies alone suggest.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The world’s official covid-19 death count is 4.5m but our new machine learning model estimates that between 9.3m and 18.1m people have died. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Tap the link in our bio here to explore our data team's daily estimates of excess deaths, by region and by country.
